elements.title: Chauncey Yellow Robe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 1927, Native American activist Chauncey Yellow Robe (pictured) and the Lakota Sioux tribe "adopted" President Calvin Coolidge to thank him for supporting the 1924 Indian Citizenship Act?

elements.title: feed a cold, starve a fever (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the old adage "feed a cold, starve a fever" was first published in a 1574 dictionary?

elements.title: Charles Redd (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Utah state representative Charles Redd successfully proposed the legalization of horse racing and betting in 1925, only to successfully propose making it illegal again two years later?

elements.title: Cathedral of Our Lady of Seven Sorrows (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Cathedral of Our Lady of Seven Sorrows in Suzhou is known for its "hybridity" of Chinese and Western architecture?

elements.title: Volin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Jewish anarchist Volin refused to flee Nazi-occupied France as he believed that a revolution would follow the liberation of France?

elements.title: a Florida TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Comcast removed a Florida TV station from its lineup for allegedly broadcasting home shopping in prime time instead of its normal UPN programming?

elements.title: John Spencer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that John Spencer won a World Snooker Championship on his first attempt in 1969?

elements.title: Nothing, Forever (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Nothing, Forever is completely procedurally generated?
